climbs.name: Suzie's Lip Cheeze
climbs.fa: Cameron Burns and Paul Fehlau, March 1990

content.description:
This route is found on the far left side of Dutzi Rock and shares a start with Suzie's Cream Squeeze.

Climb past the bolt on Suzie's Cream Squeeze and then move slightly right and up a slab past three more bolts to the top of the rock.

Not a great route by any means but a step up in quality perhaps from Suzie's CS. Half a star out of five.
content.protection: 4 bolts, pro to 3" for the anchor

content.description: This route, on the left edge of the south face of Dutzi Rock, looks better than it is. You can go all the way to the top, or stop at a bush w/ rap slings. This small bush is a sketchy rap anchor.
content.protection: Good gear & rests for a beginner leader. Medium cams are helpful.

content.description: Crux is right off the ground.  Rock quality not the best so pull with caution!
content.location: Begin right of Suzie's Cream Squeeze.  Go up left facing flakes then up slab to top.  Walk off backside

content.description: Near the right end of the south side of Dutzi Rock is this short handcrack.

climbs.name: Pinhead
climbs.fa: Scott Stuemke & Howard King, December 1976, FFA: Dave Evans, Jeff Elgar & Randy Vogel, January 1977

content.description:
Begin just left of Elusive Butterfly; just right of a roof. Head up and right in a corner to face climbing past 2 bolts leading to an easy crack.

Renamed by the FFA (a few weeks after it was done on aid) as the original name was undoubtedly really stupid (e.g.: Suzie's Cream Squeeze) and the route went free at a very moderate grade.

This offwidth crack through a roof is a classic exercise in bathanging and awkward lip enounters. If you don't fancy hanging upside down, it has gone with a more conventional horizontal squeeze approach and would be more easily protected that way with readily available cams (6 friend/camalot). The crux is turning the lip, and could go many ways depending on your imagination and/or size of body parts. Strenuous, unique, and whimsically absurd.

* It is not located on the Dutzi Rock proper, but closer to the Echo Cove area (see location section below for more detail).
content.protection: Protection on lead would be difficult for this if you bathang it, at least for the first part of the roof. The lip at the start is about 9", tapering deeper. You could likely push a 6 friend way up in there, but then cleaning or walking it would be a problem or entirely out of the question. Closer to the lip  a constriction goes as narrow as 5", but on these bathang jobs you want to place the pro behind you so climbing around it would present it's own problems. If you own some Valley Giants, or are bold enough to solo out far enough to get a solid 6 friend, you're loving it.  If you use a horizontal squeeze approach rather than a bathang, you should be able to place and slide a 6" cam.  TR is easy enough to rig by tying off a tree way back and belaying from the top with the rope running through the crack. Slingshot TR would be problematic as the crack pinches off and is only about 1" where the rope would run.
content.location: Drive to Echo-tee, turn left as for Echo Cove/Rusty Wall and keep your eyes on the base of the hillside to your left. About 100 yards past the large pullout on the right used for Big Moe, there is a one car pullout on the right. Park here. The route is easily spotted as a wide crack splitting a roof on a large boulder, about 200 yards from the road, at the base of the hillside opposite the entrance into to Echo Cove.

climbs.name: Fingers on a Landscape
climbs.fa: Lynn Hill and Charles Cole, January 1980

content.description:
This is the right-slanting finger/hand crack about 20' left of a prominent hand crack -

Shakin' the Shirts

.
content.protection: Gear to 2.5", with extra thin gear

content.description: This route climbs the obvious right leaning ramp/dihedral on the south side of Dutzi Rock. Good rock and nice line make this a fun climb. The pro is sparse however, making it a bit sporty of a lead if 5.6/7 is near your limit.

Fun summit just a short walk from the HV backloop campsites.  Start on the second tier where Shakin' The Shirt tops out.  Go up crack or face to get around a small woody tree.  Continue up that short dihedral.  If you top out just about straight up above that dihedral, there're nice placements for gear anchor.  If you instead veer up and right near the top as JT West topo suggests, there's no readily available gear features for anchoring, as in only go that way if comfortable with topside body belay.
content.protection: Double rack to 2" plus one 3" cam, gear anchor.
content.location: Walk off, down the west gap.  Fun adventurous downscramble.
